I originally predicted 50% - too close to call.  But now I think republican voters writing-in another candidate instead of voting for Moore is going to give Jones the win, plus Jones seems to be getting the high turnout among Democrats, especially young people and African Americans that people weren't sure he was actually going to be able to get. A note: I've seen a few comments saying they believe Alabamians will say they will vote for Jones on a poll (or put a Jones sign on their lawn), but privately they will still vote for Moore, and those commentators may be right.  But I think they are also underestimating the amount of Republicans who will say they will vote for Moore, but privately won't, because they are not willing to admit they won't vote for the Republican nominee. 
I think saying that people are willing to say they will vote for Jones but actually won't is the outside perspective, I think in Alabama there is far more social pressure to publicly say you will vote republican (though I am also an outsider, so I might be very wrong). I think there might be a significant amount of Republicans in Alabama who will privately choose to write-in a different republican instead of voting for Jones because of Alabama cultural pressure not to vote for a Democrat and/or to satisfy their religious loyalty to the republican party. In an election this close, there doesn't have to be that many of them to make a difference.

Let me make this simple - Alabama voters will rally on two points - Moore hasn'r rec'd due process and therefore is seen as the aggrieved part, and Jones is pro abortion a litmus test item in the south. So they vote for a possible molester and a (as they see him) a known baby killer. Advantage Moore, on record turnout.

Bullish on Jones for a few reasons: 1) National context - Democrats will show up in higher numbers than expected given opposition to Trump (as we saw in VA, and as occurred in reverse with the Tea Party after Obama's election)
2) Roy Moore - extreme enough that we've got to subtract a few points for Republicans who just can't stomach voting for him (and the sexual allegations don't help)
3) The polls - as 538 points out, most of the polls have been robo calls, not the gold standard.  Of the surveys that used lived interviews, Jones has been tied or lead Moore:  https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/what-the-hell-is-happening-with-these-alabama-polls/

Still at 100% that Moore will win. I don't think it matters if Alabamians believe the allegations against Moore. To the type of Christians that inhabit Alabama - and a great many other places in the U.S. - Moore's sexual misconduct is a moral lapse that anyone can fall prey to. Abortion, on the other hand, is considered literally Satanic, and support for it is regarded as a conscious choice to align with evil. The fact that the allegations against Moore are decades old conforms to a theology of redemption and personal transformation through Christianity. I don't know if Moore has made that case, but it's possible that his voters subconsciously make it for him. So when weighing comparative moral lapses, Jones may be considered the greater malefactor simply because of his stance on abortion. For evangelical, fundamentalist and Pentacostal voters, abortion is not just a policy issue. As for spending, I think it's at best irrelevant in this case. The Democrats spent a fortune on advertising for Ossoff - far more than Handel spent - and Ossoff lost. If you are the pro-choice, anti-gun candidate in Alabama, spending on ads won't help you.  Similarly, we keep seeing stories about how committed Republicans can never bring themselves to vote for Moore. This is unsurprising, because the Republican organization in Alabama backed Strange in the primary; Moore was the insurgent candidate. I read an article yesterday that quoted a stalwart Republican woman who couldn't stand Moore. Then they gave her background, and she's related to officers of the state party, and to Republican officeholders in Alabama. People like her may swing the vote to Jones, but I think they are hardly representative, and unless they turn out in large numbers, will have little effect. Perhaps more importantly, I think the Atticus Finch style liberalism that Jones represents has little purchase in Alabama (or anywhere else) anymore. America has changed, politics have coarsened, and behavior that people once considered out-of-bounds is now acceptable, because the only thing that matters is political power. From what I know about Jones, he is portraying himself as a decent man, and therefore worthy of the office. He may well be a decent man, but unfortunately that's not enough anymore - in fact, it may be an impediment. In any case, his stances on abortion and gun rights will, for many voters, disqualify him. Ideally, (from a party standpoint) the Democrats would run a decent man who a majority of people are willing to vote for. As it is, the Republicans appear to be running an indecent man who a majority of people are unwilling to vote against. That's why I think Moore will win. We'll see this evening.

One does wish people would stop referring to elections as "races."  They are not races, nor any other sort of game, and using sport metaphors gives vast numbers of Americans the wrong idea about what is going on.  The important thing in an election is not who is ahead at any particular moment, but about what the winner will do once elected.   In any case, the good white Christians of Alabama will not vote for a Democrat, no matter who the Rs put up.  In the olden days of of the Solid South (which was solidly D, this being a moment in history when the Republican party was the less racialist), such voters were referred to as "yellow-dog" Democrats, of whom it was said they would vote for a yellow dog on the Democratic ticket rather than any Republican.  The party has changed, but the principle hasn't. I see that this morning some polls have put the D ahead, and it does after all depend more on turnout this year than usually.  If lots of Rs stay home (or if a few of the brighter ones switch), and there is a good-sized black vote, and both of the white Democrats vote for their lad, there is a smallish chance he will win.  I would love to be completely wrong about my projected outcome, but I think I would need a lot more bourbon to switch it.

Today the state votes to fill the Senate seat left vacant when Donald Trump appointed as attorney-general Jeff Sessions, who had held it for 20 years. Alabama is deeply Republican—Mr Trump won it by 28 points, and no Democrat has been elected senator for 25 years—but this race is too close to call, largely because the Republican nominee is Roy Moore. He believes homosexuality should be illegal, Muslims should be barred from serving in Congress and the constitution exists to foster Christianity. Several women have accused him of offences, which he denies, ranging from sexual harassment to assault; most were teenagers at the time of the alleged incidents. Doug Jones, the Democrat, is a genial former federal prosecutor whose scrappy campaign caught fire. Mr Moore retains strong support among white evangelicals, around half of Alabama’s electorate. To win, Mr Jones needs strong African-American turnout, and votes from Republican business-owners rightly worried about the state’s reputation

I understand that this prediction is completely subjective and lacks any quantitative analysis; but this race has been so close that I think the "tie" will go in Moore's favor.
Roy Moore is probably going to the United States Senate. The median of 6 polls in the last 7 days is Moore up by 4.5 points.
I seriously hope that I'm wrong on this. I'd much rather blow up my Brier score than be right in this case.

Running a naive aggregate, of the last 15 surveys, including the more traditional Fox News poll and the Online Survey Monkey poll, I'm coming up with 48% of the vote going to Roy Moore (R) and 45% of the vote going to Doug Jones (D), the margin of error at 98% confidence interval being 0.09% (Sample size is 20000). The probability that Roy Moore is leading the actual race based on the 15 most recent polls is then 60.2% and the probability that Doug Jones is leading the actual race is 39.8%. My latest forecast reflects much more uncertainty. I ran this same forecast model as a test against Brexit (retroactively), and got 61% probability of Remain, vs 39%. That means my model would have failed for Brexit. It's nice to be able to place a higher certainty on the election and get a nice score, but at that point I'm not using statistics, but speculating. I wish I had time to correct for the bias the polling organizations and improve the model, but this will have to do for now.

Others have said there are no good polls in Alabama because this race is impossible to model.   Here's some interesting take from Monmouth:   "If the turnout for Tuesday's special election looks like the 2014 midterm, Moore has a 48% to 44% lead over Jones. 
But if the election looks like turnout models based on the most high-profile statewide election of 2017 so far, last month's gubernatorial race in Virginia, the two men are tied at 46% of the vote. 
And if voter demographics resemble the 2016 presidential election, Jones has 48% of the vote to Moore's 45%, according to Monmouth." I am going to give Moore the edge because it is Alabama and because I think that as disastrous as the Trump admin may seem for many of us -- given his approval ratings -- the Republican base that got him elected, and specially the evangelical Christians, still strongly support Trump. Based on that, and on the question of "Alabama values" voting against Jones, and only 17% believing allegations against Moore, think the majority will vote to elect Moore to the Senate.
I am giving live interview polls more credence than robocalls.

OUTER VIEW 
I reviewed the  Real Clear Politics Polls from October thru today, paying particular attention to the margins of error (MOE). I discounted polls for which the MOE overlapped indicating no clear winner.  Then I calculated  weighted average proportions from the remaining polls (Non-overlapping) and had Moore 49%, Jones 43%, Undecided 6%.  INNER VIEW : The hot button issues are  allegations of Sexual misconduct against  Moore, his being twice removed from a judicial office, his presumably strong stance on 2nd Amendment rights, His traditional Republican credentials weigh heavily in his favor.
With Jones, the issues are Moore's attempts to paint him as a liberal Democrat controlled by the Democratic leadership in the Senate, and his being pro-choice.  In his  favor was his being the successful lead prosecutor in the conviction of two KKKK members in the 16th Street Church bombing. There will be maybe two SCOTUS vacancies that could occur on his watch. Alabama voters are strongly concerned about protection of the unborn, and 1st amendment rights regarding gender issues and marriage rights. 
 Alabama Secretary of State projects overall voter turnout at 25%, since this is a special election and may garner less interest.
The most recent poll has Moore at 2.2% points ahead.  If the Afro-American vote turnout is strong (over 25%), It will be very close.
 Probability of winning:  Moore 72%, Jones 28%.

I think with the outsized campaign spending  over the last month or so (10.2 -1.8 million) by Doug Jones and the fact that he has been on the campaign trail aggressively for the last 14 days while Roy Moore has not, puts Doug  Jones in the box seat. The difference will be voter turnout. A higher than average Republican turnout will be necessary. Are they energized or disillusioned with Moore? Roy Moore is staying closer to his base while Doug Jones is pushing his boundaries, by crisscrossing Alabama. My base rate for spending favoring a candidate is 86%. When I factor in voter turnout or non-turnout, the numbers move to democratic support shows a high voter turnout. I think it may be enough to have a Doug Jones victory. Also the base Roy Moore (60+ years) may be dwarfed by the surge in African American support for Doug Jones (450-550 Moore) to (600 -700) Jones. If the turn out is high, then its tight for Moore.

(I'm often wrong about U.S. politics.) I've made the basic point before, but here's some elaboration: I think a single political issue---abortion---will determine the outcome of the Alabama senate race. My understanding is that in Alabama enough voters tend vote against pro-choice candidates (like the Democrat in this race) and for anti-abortion candidates (like the Republican in this race) to make the race's outcome a foregone conclusion. (For recent coverage, see, e.g., [1] NPR: https://goo.gl/Xj6WjB , [2] Breitbart: https://goo.gl/zBDBHp .)   A 2014 Pew Poll for Alabama estimated its percentage of people who "Believe Abortion Should Be Illegal in All/Most Cases" (58%) lags only two other states---Arkansas (60%) and Mississippi (59%)---although these reported differences may be within the margin of polling error.[3] https://goo.gl/by9HjD For those who’d prefer a picture of Republican strength in Alabama, the following map shows the 2014 results for the election of Jefferson Beauregard Sessions III, whose seat is the subject of this runoff. (Dark red is 90%-99% for Jeff Sessions; red is 80-89% for Jeff Sessions; those are the only colors on the map, if you don't feel like clicking.) [4] https://goo.gl/rQjNu9  In the 2016 Senate Election (a presidential election year; such years usually generate higher Democratic turnout) Republican Richard Shelby won by a large margin (63.9% to 35.8%). Similar results extend back in every election for  another 2.5 decades or so. The last Democrat who won a senate seat in Alabama, Howell Heflin, is dead. He won his last election in 1990 (& had been incumbent since 1979). Excerpts from Heflin’s wikipedia article: “He strongly opposed legal abortion and all gun control laws. [Gibson note: not true of the current Democratic candidate.] Heflin supported prayer in public schools and opposed extending federal laws against discrimination to homosexuals… he was one of only two Democrats in the Senate to vote against the Family and Medical Leave Act. He occasionally voted with Republicans on taxes [and was considered to have the option of appointment and confirmation to the U.S. Supreme Court by Republican Ronald Regan had he wanted the job, which he did not].” (Heflin voted with Democrats on affirmative action and opposed a confederate flag patent renewal attempt by the Daughters of the Confederacy; by contrast, his uncle, "Cotton Tom" Heflin (also a U.S. Senator) was a white supremacist who bragged of shooting a black man on a Washington, D.C. streetcar (charges dismissed) and was said by a Grand Wizard of the KKK to have been a member of that organization.) Technically, in 1992 a Democrat *did* win a senate seat, but that was Richard Shelby, i.e. the currently Republican Senator Richard Shelby last re-elected in 2016. Shelby switched to Republican in 1994, but he’s been an incumbent senator since 1986---more than three decades. “Shelby opposes abortion and has stated on his Senate campaign website that Roe v. Wade is "...terribly flawed on both a constitutional and moral basis." Shelby also opposes taxpayer funding of Planned Parenthood and has voted against a short-term funding bill in Congress because it did not defund Planned Parenthood.” [Wikipedia.] The most recent Senator before those listed above was Republican Jeremiah Denton. From a 1981 New York Times article on (the first female Supreme Court) Justice O’Connor’s confirmation proceedings: “Senator Denton said that while he regarded Judge O'Connor as a “superior candidate,” a “fine lady,” and a “distinguished jurist,” he could not vote to confirm her because she had refused to criticize the 1973 Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion.”[5 [endnote]]  Before that, there was Democrat Donald Wilbur Stewart who’d won a special election in ’78. He was up for reelection in 1980. His opponent in the 1980 Democratic Primary, “Folsom[,] called Stewart "the worst U.S. senator in Alabama history" for supporting federally funded abortion, forced busing over long distances and the Equal Rights Amendment.”[6] Folsom defeated Stewart in the primary and then lost to Denton in the general election. So I believe 1978-January 1981 may have been the only time Alabama has ever had a "pro-choice"/non-anti-abortion Senator (assuming the veracity of his primary opponent's words on the narrow point of his vote for federal funding of abortion). The next seat back was Democrat (which back then in the south could still mean Dixiecrat) James Allen who won the 1968 election and upon his death in 1978 was succeeded in office by his wife Maryon Pittman Allen, whose reported criticism of segregationist Alabama Democratic Governor George Wallace contributed to her failure to get re-elected. Although she claimed her remarks were distorted, many Alabamans objected to her even agreeing to be interviewed by the Washington Post, which had published the remarks. [Note the same Washington Post broke the Roy Moore story and sponsored this GJO Challenge/Forecasting Problem.] I’m not aware of his wife’s expressing any opinions on abortion during her brief, unelected stint as Senator (Alabama has twice appointed a female Senator (each time to fill a vacancy) but never elected one), but James Allen said of the Supreme Court’s 1973 decision upholding abortion: “I’m shocked at the decision… bad logic, bad law, bad morals.”[7] At the time of those remarks, the man holding the other Alabama Senate seat, John Sparkman, was most famous for being segregationist (e.g., signed the Southern Manifesto opposing Brown v. Board of Education after having been the Vice Presidential candidate on Agnew's ticket a couple years before); Sparkman was also an opponent of abortion.[8] I believe that's everybody from Alabama who held a U.S. Senate seat after Roe v. Wade (1973) (the case in which the Supreme Court held that a woman's right to an abortion was protected by the Fourteenth Amendment). [9] I’m surprised anyone thinks there is any chance Roy Moore could lose this election, but I've been very wrong before about U.S. political races. One last comment about polling numbers in this race: I don't trust them. When confronted with pollsters I expect some ultimately pro-Moore voters who feel conflicted (due to the sexual assault allegations) to be more likely to clam up or provide inaccurate information than in a normal election. An Alabama historian recently explained the tension between the Alabama electorate's preference for both "saints" and former Governor "Kissing Jim" Folsom (who boasted of kissing 50,000 women/girls starting with sixteen-year-olds), "If sophisticated, better-educated cultures that are less evangelical make fun of you and your people you react with a 'bunker mentality."[10] [5] http://www.nytimes.com/1981/09/16/us/panel-approves-judge-o-connor.html

[9] https://www.oyez.org/cases/1971/70-18
[10] https://www.npr.org/2017/12/09/569450216/before-roy-moore-alabama-grappled-with-kissing-jim

The Republican candidate, Judge Roy Moore, will not win the Senate seat.  Democrat Doug Jones will win the seat.  The reasons are low voter turnout, arithmetic, GOP stupidity, and people of color adding to voter turnout.   1. This will be a low turnout election. The primary turnout was 18%, http://www.al.com/news/birmingham/index.ssf/2017/09/low_turnout_expected_for_roy_m.html and the average midterm is 50ish%. The Presidential election turnout was 61ish%. If people of color turn out, Jones wins. Neither Cook Political nor 538 have even mentioned these fact- low midterm turnout + people of color voting. The reasons for low voter turnout are Moore's unpopularity and the fact that the GOP chose to hold this election in mid-December, when people are involved with Christmas and family.  They could have called the election for the usual November election day but they chose not to, looking for low voter turnout.  It is a case of careful what you wish for.  2. Arithmetic and Moore’s unpopularity
Look at the August primary results. 589,175 voters went to the polls, according to unofficial results from the secretary of state's office. http://www.al.com/news/birmingham/index.ssf/2017/09/low_turnout_expected_for_roy_m.html  Of those, 72 percent voted in the Republican primary. That’s 424,206 votes.  Let’s highlight this:  August GOP turnout was 72% of 18% of registered voters.  Pretty low turnout.   Of those, 258,000 all voted for a Republican other than Moore. They might be disgusted with him. Now assume some of those Republicans don’t vote in December. So that 258,000 votes is about how much you have to increase Democratic voter turnout.   3. People of color are 29% of the state's registered voters. They are part of the Democrats  but not all of them.  They are presumed to be 100% Democratic voters.  The state of Alabama claims 3,330,802 registered voters. http://www.al.com/opinion/index.ssf/2016/11/are_99_percent_of_alabama_vote.html. 29% of all registered voters = 280,120. 280,120 – 258,000 = 22,120 votes.  That’s all it takes. 22,120 votes to beat Judge Roy Moore.  If Jones wins, it will prove that other southern states are also winnable if you focus on black voter turnout.Before they were killed, MLK and RFK were going to put us on the right track, with organized black church, labor, and worker turnout.... A Democratic victory in an Alabama Senate race would rank as one of the most improbable, astonishing outcomes in the last few years of improbable, astonishing political events. The Roy Moore-Doug Jones contest can be seen as a mad experiment to test the limits of Republican strength in Alabama, perhaps the toughest for Democrats in the country. It might be reasonable to say that if Democrats can’t win it here and now, they just can’t win it as long as the country remains so divided by race, religion and education. It is probably far too soon to get a good sense of where the race will end up, especially since it is not clear whether a write-in candidate will enter the race. Recent polls have not been of the highest quality, but they suggest a tight race. There’s a simple reason Mr. Moore is still very competitive: Alabama is just that conservative.

The Post's publication of the accusations against Moore will quite possibly have no effect on the election, even if that are proven to be true (which for all I know, they are). The Post probably thinks these accusations will be considered disqualifying by religious people. Nothing could be further from the truth. The type of religious people who are going to vote for Moore believe in a theology of redemption, and that all humans are by nature sinners. The important thing is not Moore's past sins, but his current acceptance of Jesus. To think these accusations, by themselves, would be considered disqualifying by religious people in Alabama is to completely misunderstand Christian theology as it is preached among evangelicals and fundamentalists. Moore is accused of engaging in inappropriate conduct with underage girls, and one instance of sexual abuse because the girl was under the age of consent. This is a serious matter, but it would almost certainly not be regarded as worse than what tens of thousands of his voters had done before they were "saved." This is the whole point of becoming "saved;" to a religious voter in Alabama, of course Moore was a sleazeball before he was saved. So was everybody else. To believers in this type of Christian theology, you can't judge people for their past sins, because everyone would be found wanting. What matters to them is his current faith. The validity of the theology itself is irrelevant; this is the reality of how a great many voters are going to see this. So here are three scenarios that might play out: 1) No further evidence is given of Moore's inappropriate conduct - result: Alabama voters consider the whole thing a hatchet job by the Washington Post. Moore wins.
2) The allegations are irrefutably proven - result: Moore appeals to the voters that he has been redeemed and has received the Holy Spirit. Moore wins.
3) (Least likely, imo) Moore is forced off the ticket and a replacement is found to run on the Republican line. Moore's replacement wins. So whatever happens, a Republican wins. I think Moore can ride this out and win in December - even if the allegations prove to be true - and in any case, neither the allegations against Moore nor the replacement of Moore by another candidate will necessarily induce people to vote for Jones.
